user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of init_rand_data:
```c
static int
init_rand_data (void)
{
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
  int fd;
  ssize_t len;
  size_t off;

  fd = open ("/dev/urandom", O_RDONLY);
  if (-1 == fd)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Failed to open '%s': %s\n",
             "/dev/urandom",
             strerror (errno));
    return 0;
  }
  for (off = 0; off < sizeof(rand_data); off += (size_t) len)
  {
    len = read (fd, rand_data, 8);
    if (0 > len)
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "Failed to read '%s': %s\n",
               "/dev/urandom",
               strerror (errno));
      (void) close (fd);
      return 0;
    }
  }
  (void) close (fd);
#else  /* Native W32 */
  HCRYPTPROV cc;
  BOOL b;

  b = CryptAcquireContext (&cc,
                           NULL,
                           NULL,
                           PROV_RSA_FULL,
                           CRYPT_VERIFYCONTEXT);
  if (FALSE == b)
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to acquire crypto provider context: %lu\n",
             (unsigned long) GetLastError ());
    return 0;
  }
  b = CryptGenRandom (cc, sizeof(rand_data), (BYTE *) rand_data);
  if (FALSE == b)
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to generate 8 random bytes: %lu\n",
             GetLastError ());
  }
  CryptReleaseContext (cc, 0);
  if (FALSE == b)
    return 0;
#endif /* Native W32 */

  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expression in this function is invariant as described by MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Detailed reasoning:

- The only loop is: for (off = 0; off < sizeof(rand_data); off += (size_t) len)
  - Although sizeof(rand_data) is a compile-time constant, the controlling expression (off < sizeof(rand_data)) depends on the variable off, which is updated each iteration. Therefore the controlling expression is not invariant. (Note: a runtime condition where read returns 0 could cause an infinite loop, but that is a dynamic behavior issue, not an invariant controlling-expression violation under Rule 14.3.)

- All if statements use comparisons against variables or results of functions/calls and thus are not invariant:
  - if (-1 == fd) depends on the result of open()
  - if (0 > len) depends on len set by read()
  - if (FALSE == b) depends on b set by CryptAcquireContext/CryptGenRandom

- There are no while or do-while loops with constant controlling expressions. The do-while exception is not applicable because no do-while exists.

- Preprocessor conditional (#if ! defined(_WIN32) ...) does not create a controlling expression at runtime and is not relevant to Rule 14.3.

Given the above, there are no code fragments in this function that should be investigated specifically for invariant controlling expressions under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
